page.title: 01Wroxall and its surroundings
page.content: In the south of the Isle of Wight, chalk downs 200 metres high dominate the block, sloping steeply into the Wroxall valley in the East and more gently to the Yar valley in the West. Predominantly agricultural,the varied soils facilitate rough grazing for sheep,dairy farming and arable crops. Wroxall is the largest settlement with a Post Office,2 pubs,restaurant tea-shop,several shops and 2 churches. There is a caravan site nd the area is well served with footpaths. Although "Warochesselle" was a Manor in Domesday Book and the 17th Century Appuldurcombe House stands on the ruins of a 13th C. Abbey,most of the village is relatively modern. Much building took place after the arrival of the railway in 1866 and since 1975 a housing estate,Community Centre and a new Primary School have been built.
